content.description:
As implied, the route follows the obvious wide crack and right around the roof to a blocky finish. Either finish up on the shared anchors for the routes here, or build your own and then rap.

The first bulge in the wide crack is the crux and is insecure wide jamming with poor feet.
content.location: The furthest route right on the main face.

content.description: Very low angled climb just to the left of Flake Route.  Crux is located right at the beginning, when getting up over a small bulge to gain the higher crack system.  Overall, a good first trad lead for a beginner, but nothing too exciting other than that.
content.protection: A standard set of cams and wire stoppers.  A size 4 camalot would be useful, but not needed.
content.location: Located to the left of Flake Route, this route starts right next to a small pine tree/bush.  Use the same anchors as Flake Route.  This route follows the obvious wide crack up the left side of the rock when looking at Flake Route.

content.description: A chimminy climb right of the 5.5.

This nice moderate difficulty route follows a left facing flake system in the middle of the SW face. There are a few large chickenheads on the edge of the flake. The climbing is never any harder than 5.5, and is a good introduction to climbing on City of Rocks granite. Very enjoyable.
content.protection: A few medium size cams up to a 2 Camalot, and a few small-medium wired stoppers and several standard length runners.
content.location: There is a good 2 bolt anchor at the top of the route, complete with chains and welded-shuts for descent by rappel. A single 60 meter rope is adequate.

content.description: 3 bolts up a steep face. No anchors, build a gear anchor.
content.location: Far right line in a small cove, by the fire pit.
